Mitchener was shot down and captured as a POW during WWII after a bombing mission in Germany. On the night of January 27, 1945, the men at Stalag Luft III were evacuated. Hitler had ordered the Luftwaffe to evacuate the prison camps that were about to be liberated by the Red Army. After a blizzard march and horrendous conditions, the men arrived in Nuremberg. Hunger was a danger, as well as Allied bombings. Eventually, the men were forced to move onwards towards Munich. They were liberated in late April.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This page is a poem,"Prisoner's Prayer." Mitchener notes that it was memorized by a POW from scratchings on the wall in a Vienna transition camp. The poem asks for God's protection for airmen facing "shell, flak, fire, and foe." He writes, in part, "Lord, guard and guide the men who fly/Thru the great spaces of the sky/Protect them as they take to air/In morning light and sunshine fair."

Hardy A. Mitchener, Jr. was shot down and captured as a POW during World War II after a bombing mission in Germany. He served as a second Lieutenant in the 509th Bombardment Squadron, 351st Bombardment Group, 8th Air Force. After men were captured, they were often told, "For you, the war is over," and this served to demoralize the men. Men who were kept as POWs often suffered from depression during their internment. This was referred to as "barbed wire disease." The men longed for freedom.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This image was drawn by Hardy A. Mitchener, Jr. in the diary that he received during his stay at a German prisoner of war camp. It pictures an airman, probably Mitchener himself, falling out of the sky in a parachute. His plane has been shot down, and a fire is visible in the background where his plane has crashed. Two signs are pictured, one which reads, "Welcome to Sagan, City of 2000 Dreams," and the other reads, "To Dulag Registration Center." Mitchener is about to be taken prisoner.

Hardy A. Mitchener, Jr. was shot down during World War II after a bombing mission in Germany. He served as a second lieutenant in the 509th Bombardment Squadron, 351st Bombardment Group, 8th Air Force. His B-17G had bombed the aircraft plant in Oschersleben and was headed back to England when he was shot down. One member of the crew, Lester L. Kunz, was killed. Mitchener was taken into Dulag Luft for processing and then to Stalag Luft III for internment.

Mitchener was shot down during World War II after a bombing mission in Germany and sent to Stalag Luft III as a POW. He served as a second lieutenant in the 509th Bombardment Squadron, 351st Bombardment Group, 8th Air Force. Life as an American prisoner of war in Germany involved hunger, cold, boredom, and overcrowded conditions. Stalag Luft III is known for the famous Great Escape that took place in late March 1944, in which 80 POWs attempted to escape, but Mitchener was not imprisoned at this time.

World War, 1939-1945 -- Europe; Prisoners of war; Diaries
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is another page of the Christmas program that was given to the POWs at Stalag Luft III in 1944. It includes the lyrics to "Silent Night" and a schedule of the theatrical entertainment from Dec. 20-Dec. 23. Some of the events include "Holiday Harmonies" and "Traveling Troupes" to give entertainment in all prison blocks, and the radio play,"Christmas Carol," by Dickens.

Mitchener was shot down and captured as a POW after a bombing mission in Germany and sent to Stalag Luft III in Sagan, Germany, now a part of Poland. Christmas Day in 1944 at Stalag Luft III was cold but clear. The men were given Red Cross parcels with canned turkey, cookies, and plum pudding. The Germans gave them party hats and noisemakers, but the atmosphere was still grim. The Allied troops were stalled along the Siegfried Line, and the men feared that they would be prisoners indefinitely.
